#Derivatives in R

## A
```{r}
fx <- expression(x^2)

x <- 3

df_dx <- D(expr = fx, name = 'x')

eval(expr = df_dx)
```
##B
```{r}
pa <- expression(2*(3*a + 2)^4 - 5)

a <- 1.2

dp_da <- D(expr = pa, name = 'a')

eval(expr = dp_da)
```
##C
```{r}
gt <- expression((-4*t)/((t^2) + 1)^3)

t <- 0

dg_dt <- D(expr = gt, name = 't')

eval(expr = dg_dt)
```
##Higher order univariate derivatives
```{r}
gz <- expression(4.6 - (1.9*z^3))

dg_dz <- D(expr = gz, name = 'z')

#eval(dg_dz, 'z') gives error because R is looking for something to plug in, but we did not define z. Just call the dg_dz because it takes the derivative without needing a value to plug in.
dg_dz

d2g_dz2 <- D(expr = dg_dz, name = 'z')

d2g_dz2

#eval(d2g_dz2, 'z')
```
